```{r}
library(usethis)
library(devtools)
install("C:/Users/16341/Desktop/winter2022/stats230/Multiplication")
library(Multiplication)
library(bench)
#3*3 matrices & vectors of lenght=3
a<-rnorm(9)
A<-matrix(a,nrow = 3,ncol = 3)
b<-runif(9)
B<-matrix(b,nrow = 3,ncol = 3)
x<-rnorm(3)
m1<-bench::mark(Multiply_mv(A,B,x, vector_first = T))
m2<-bench::mark(Multiply_mv(A,B,x, vector_first = F))
m1$median;m2$median  #median of running time
m1$total_time;m2$total_time   #total time

#5*5 matrices & vectors of lenght=5
a<-rnorm(25)
A<-matrix(a,nrow = 5,ncol = 5)
b<-runif(25)
B<-matrix(b,nrow = 5,ncol = 5)
x<-rnorm(5)

m1<-bench::mark(Multiply_mv(A,B,x, vector_first = T))
m2<-bench::mark(Multiply_mv(A,B,x, vector_first = F))
m1$median;m2$median  #median of running time
m1$total_time;m2$total_time   #total time


#10*10 matrices & vectors of lenght=10
a<-rnorm(100)
A<-matrix(a,nrow = 10,ncol = 10)
b<-runif(100)
B<-matrix(b,nrow = 10,ncol = 10)
x<-rnorm(10)

m1<-bench::mark(Multiply_mv(A,B,x, vector_first = T))
m2<-bench::mark(Multiply_mv(A,B,x, vector_first = F))
m1$median;m2$median  #median of running time
m1$total_time;m2$total_time   #total time
```
#Analysis
Based on the comparison of running time of the two ways. We can see that computing the multiplication involving vectors will lead to a shorter running time than the way that computes the product of matrices first. And as the dimension of matrices grows, the difference becomes more and more significant.
